items.title: The billion dollar deportation deal Australia doesn't want to talk about ft. David Shoebridge
items.summary: Australia is expected to spend billions of dollars to deport non-citizens to the small Pacific nation of Nauru. Meanwhile, Pauline Hanson as repeated a years-old stunt, environment laws have passed, and Barnaby Joyce has cosied up with One Nation. Greens Senator David Shoebridge talks about the Nauru deal, after a translation of an interview with the nation's president was controversially put on the record in the Senate.

items.title: Exclusive: El Jannah CEO speaks with SBS as company goes global & ASX rises
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with El Jannah CEO Brett Houldin as the charcoal chicken company secures international funding valuing it at hundreds of millions of dollars, allowing it to quadruple its national footprint and explore options in the Middle-East; plus the week on the sharemarket with Tony Sycamore from IG Markets Securities Limited.

items.title: Trump announces migration freeze for ‘third world countries’ after national guard shooting
items.summary: The US president said the plan would include cases approved under former president Joe Biden's administration.

items.title: Increased bushfire risk in parts of Australia this summer, fire authorities warn
items.summary: The latest bushfire outlook forecasts an increased fire risk across parts of Australia this summer. Despite recent rainfall in the country's southeast, authorities say it won't take long for a blaze to take hold.

items.title: Police officer convicted over teen's death will appeal | Evening News Bulletin 28 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, a police officer vows to appeal his conviction over the death of an Aboriginal teenager, arrests after a man is shot dead in a daylight attack in Sydney. And in cricket, big calls as the squad is unveiled for the second Ashes test.

items.title: Why these near-identical Chinese restaurants have caused mass confusion
items.summary: Its plastic grapes and braised eggplant are an iconic Sydney staple. But Chinese Noodle House's closure has sparked grief ... and confusion.

items.title: Trump says US will begin taking land action against alleged Venezuelan drug traffickers
items.summary: The announcement follows months of military strikes against alleged drug boats in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 28 November 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Arrests made in connection with deadly Hong Kong fire
items.summary: A blaze that began in bamboo scaffolding at Hong Kong’s Wang Fuk Court has become the city’s worst fire in decades, killing at least 83 people and leaving hundreds missing. Police have arrested two directors, and an engineering consultant of a firm contracted to perform maintenance on the buildings.

items.title: 94 dead in Hong Kong towers inferno | Midday News Bulletin 28 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Hong Kong's high-rise fire still out of control as the death toll rises, two men charged with assaulting police in Melbourne protests last month. And in football, Aston Villa scores a 2-1 victory against the Young Boys in the Europa League.

items.title: Iran claims Australia 'complicit' with Israel as it shares 'disgust' at IRGC terror listing
items.summary: Iran has denounced Australia's listing of the IRGC as state sponsors of terror, accusing the government of acting on fabricated claims.

items.title: PM praises 'yes-alition' as environmental reforms pass and parliament adjourns for the year
items.summary: Politicians have returned for a final sitting hour to secure Labor's environmental Christmas win.

items.title: Trump blames Biden-era vetting after national guard member killed in Washington shooting
items.summary: Sarah Beckstrom was one of two national guard troops who were shot while patrolling an area near the White House on Thursday.

items.title: Israeli forces kill Palestinian men who appeared to be surrendering in West Bank raid
items.summary: Footage appeared to show Israeli security forces shoot and kill two unarmed Palestinian men who were attempting to surrender during a raid in Jenin in the occupied West Bank.

items.title: Scores dead, hundreds missing in Hong Kong high-rise blaze | Morning News Bulletin 28 November 2025
items.summary: Eighty-three people dead and hundreds missing in Hong Kong high-rise fire; Vladimir Putin responds to a proposed Ukraine peace plan; And in golf, Australian golfers chase the lead in the rain hit Australian PGA.

items.title: 'Lions of Zion' group event celebrating Israel's pager attacks condemned
items.summary: Victoria Police has said it will continue to monitor the event billed as "fun for all ages".

items.title: The most common holiday-season scams targeting Australians — and how to spot them
items.summary: Some Australians are reporting losses of up to $5,000 due to scams during the holiday shopping season.

items.title: Australia lists Iranian group as terrorist sponsors as Wong cites 'dangerous acts'
items.summary: The listing comes after the group was accused of being behind two separate arson attacks against Australia's Jewish Community.

items.title: APRA tightens lending rules, and investors continue to question rate outlook
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar about APRA's tightening of lending rules for high risk borrowers to find out if it will make a difference; plus, the day on the sharemarket with Hugh Lam from Betashares.

items.title: Australia falling well short of 2035 climate target, as Bowen concedes more work needed
items.summary: The federal government has already acknowledged tougher policies would be needed to meet the 2035 goal.

items.title: Barnaby Joyce quits Nationals after 30 years | Evening News Bulletin 27 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, former Nationals leader Barnaby Joyce quits the party after 30 years, Australia has more work to do to meet its climate targets. And in football, Liverpool's manager admits he could lose his job after a shock home ground loss in an already-rough season.

items.title: Australia is facing a hot summer — but the forecast comes with caveats
items.summary: With little rainfall, there's an increased fire risk for parts of Australia, and authorities are urging caution.

items.title: Ukraine peace plan or Putin power play? Climate COP-out and Trump’s new bromance…
items.summary: Alarm bells in Kyiv and Europe as the US is accused of presenting Putin’s peace plan for Ukraine. The ‘make or break’ COP30 climate conference ends in failure – have the petro-states won? Plus, the unlikely bromance blossoming in the Oval Office.

items.title: Don’t call abusers 'delightful': Plea from Lilie James' father as coroner issues warnings
items.summary: The NSW coroner has handed down her findings into the 2023 death of Lilie James at the hands of her ex-boyfriend.

items.title: All about Australia's biggest environmental reforms this century
items.summary: After five years of review, the government has struck a deal with the Greens to pass the largest reforms to Australia’s environmental laws in 26 years, which includes new environmental standards, protections for native forests, and the effective end of fast-tracked approvals for coal and gas projects. Despite these wins, the deal faces criticism from environmental experts.

items.title: 'Disappointing': Littleproud says Joyce let down Nationals by quitting party
items.summary: Nationals leader David Littleproud said the party had supported Barnaby Joyce through "tough times" and his "darkest moments".

items.title: 'Disappointing': Littleproud says Joyce let down Nationals by quitting party
items.summary: Nationals leader David Littleproud said the party had supported Barnaby Joyce through "tough times" and his "darkest moments".

items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Two National Guard members shot near White House
items.summary: Two U-S National Guard soldiers have been shot near the White House. A suspect has been taken into custody, and police say he was also shot - though his injuries are not life threatening.

items.title: Concerns linger about Russian advantages in new US peace plan for Ukraine
items.summary: The United States has amended its peace plan for Ukraine, reducing it to 19 points and opening a dual diplomatic track with Moscow and Kyiv. But the new plan is stirring anxiety that Donald Trump might be willing to push Ukraine to sign a peace deal heavily tilted towards Russia.

items.title: Late deal saves environmental law reforms | Midday News Bulletin 27 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, a deal will see long awaited environmental law reforms pass through the Senate today, a woman is killed in a fatal shark attack in New South Wales. And in sport, the Olympic torch has been lit in ancient Olympia and begun its journey to Milan ahead of the Winter Games.

items.title: Hong Kong apartment fire leaves dozens dead, hundreds missing
items.summary: At least 44 people have been killed in a massive blaze in Hong Kong. Authorities say around 700 residents were evacuated as firefighters battled flames that spread rapidly along bamboo scaffolding and construction netting in several high-rise towers in Hong Kong’s Tai Po district. There are now unconfirmed reports three people have been arrested over the fire.

items.title: Deepfake 'nudify' services used by thousands of Australians blocked by government
items.summary: The decision comes after students were found to be using the services to create fake nude images of their peers.

items.title: Bystander praised for heroic actions after Swiss tourist killed in NSW shark attack
items.summary: Emergency services were called to a beach at Crowdy Bay, near the Kylies Beach campground on the NSW Mid North Coast.

items.title: Major environmental laws are about to pass after 'tough' negotiations, so what are they?
items.summary: The seven bills are set to pass the Senate on the final day of the parliamentary year.

US national guard shooting suspect identified as Afghan national
items.summary: The attack is being investigated as an act of terrorism, a US official has said.

items.title: Death toll climbs in Hong Kong apartment fire | Morning News Bulletin 27 November 2025
items.summary: At least 36 dead as fire engulfs a huge block of residential towers in Hong Kong; A social media ban under challenge in Australia's High Court; And in cricket, South Africa sweeps India in the second test in Guwahati.

items.title: Sadness turns to anger in Hong Kong after city's worst fire in decades kills at least 128
items.summary: Authorities have launched a corruption probe and three construction company officials have been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter.

items.title: Sadness turns to anger in Hong Kong after city's worst fire in decades kills at least 128

items.title: The new 'widespread' scam to watch out for this Black Friday
items.summary: The scam can be difficult to spot at first glance — but there are a few red flags to watch out for.

items.title: Controversy over Melbourne event appearing to celebrate Israeli pager operation
items.summary: Lebanese and Jewish groups have condemned a planned event in Melbourne that appears to celebrate last year's Israeli pager operation in Lebanon, which killed dozens and injured thousands more. The event run by the group called Lions of Zion has been labelled 'disgraceful' - but organisers say they are celebrating what they describe as one of the most ingenious military operations in history.

items.title: Was housing the problem in Australia's 'surprising' economic check up?
items.summary: Some economists blamed housing for raising inflation but energy prices soared more than 37 per cent in the twelve months to October 2025.

items.title: Stronger inflation dashes hopes of any more interest rate cuts
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management and Belinda Allen from the Commonwealth Bank as headline inflation continues to rise at 3.8 per cent in October to find out what that means for interest rates and investments.

items.title: 'Political move' or 'invaluable tool'? Police powers to search without warrant questioned
items.summary: Victoria Police has announced expanded powers to search people in and around the Melbourne CBD without a warrant.

items.title: Senate erupts as Pauline Hanson wears burqa, gets suspended
items.summary: The Australian Senate descended into chaos as One Nation leader Pauline Hanson wore a black burqa into the chamber, prompting immediate condemnation from Muslim Senators and a forceful intervention by Foreign Minister Penny Wong. Following the rejection of her motion to ban the burqa, Ms. Hanson's stunt, which she claimed was about "protecting national security," was decried as racist and disrespectful to people of faith, ultimately leading to her suspension from the Senate.

items.title: "Total impunity": How Israeli lawlessness in the West Bank destroys the livelihoods of Palestinian farmers
items.summary: For Palestinian-Australian winemaker Sari Kassis, the reality of farming in the West Bank is one of constant physical and psychological danger. With settler violence surging in the West Bank, this year's harvest has seen a record number of Israeli attacks on farms and properties.

items.title: ‘Everywhere is not safe’: Nigeria faces spate of mass abductions
items.summary: A wave of mass abductions in Nigeria have triggered school closures across the country with anxiety, panic and anger spreading. One of these attacks saw over 300 school children kidnapped from a Catholic secondary school in the worst single kidnapping incident in five years.

items.title: 'Significant concern' about fire season as thousands under emergency warning
items.summary: Parts of the east and west are at a heightened risk for fire according to forecasters.

items.title: Government and Coalition trade blame over higher inflation figures | Evening News Bulletin 26 November 2025
items.summary: Vandalism blamed for the latest Optus outage in Melbourne; Advocates cheer an EU court ruling on same-sex marriages in the bloc; More charges laid over an alleged suspicious betting ring for the Brownlows.

items.title: Trump says peace between Russia and Ukraine is close, but Ukrainians remain defiant
items.summary: United States President Donald Trump claims a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine is close, while Volodymyr Zelenskyy has agreed in principle to a new U--proposed peace framework. However, the Ukrainian president remains wary of being pushed into accepting a deal on Russian terms, while Ukrainians seem unwilling to meet their neighbour's demands.

items.title: G20 hailed as multilateral success: but US absence casts a shadow
items.summary: World leaders have hailed the first G20 summit in Africa as a victory for multilateralism, even as they addressed challenges of climate change, inequality and war, against a backdrop of shifting geopolitical rivalries. The notable absence of President Donald Trump has raised questions the role of the United States, in a changing world order.

items.title: Ukraine ready to advance peace plan: President | Midday News Bulletin 26 November 2025
items.summary: Concern that inflation could rise when the latest figures are released today; Ukraine and the US seek agreement on a 28 point peace plan; Sydney Swans footballer Zippy Fish claims the A-F-L-W's rising star award.

items.title: What is the Cartel de los Soles and why has the US designated it a terror organisation?
items.summary: Venezuela says the organisation does not exist and the designation was a "ridiculous lie" by the US to justify an intervention.

items.title: Rental squeeze intensifies: Perth now Australia’s least affordable city
items.summary: Despite interest rates stabilising, rental stress remains unchanged across Australia. In many capital cities, households are still handing over almost a third of their income just to keep a roof over their heads. And once again, Perth has it the worst. The nation’s least affordable capital has slipped even further — recording another four per cent drop in affordability on top of last year’s record low.

items.title: Investors brace for Aussie CPI data as US rate cut looks increasingly likely
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Julia Lee from FTSE Russell to find out how investors are feeling ahead of official inflation data out on Wednesday, as traders feel increasingly confident of a US rate cut in December.

Revealed: Labor's nature law concessions in bid to win Greens or Coalition support

items.title: 'Nothing is fixing it': The devastating numbers in Australia's 'national crisis'
items.summary: Advocates fear momentum for action against gender-based violence has slowed.

items.title: Bondi stabbings: Psychiatrist downplayed killer's mental illness, inquest told
items.summary: The inquest is investigating whether Joel Cauchi's mental health was properly managed and if chances to detect his deterioration were missed.

items.title: Fair Work shake-up: gig workers secure pay rise and protection
items.summary: In a landmark agreement hailed as world-leading, the Transport Workers Union, Uber, and DoorDash have put forward a minimum standards deal for Australian gig workers to the Fair Work Commission today. This major reform guarantees food delivery riders a 25% wage increase, injury insurance, and protection from unfair algorithmic dismissal, fundamentally changing a commission-based system that workers say left them making virtually no money.

items.title: 'I felt powerless': calls to improve legal literacy for victim-survivors of sexual violence
items.summary: One in five women and one in 16 men have experienced sexual violence as adults in Australia, according to the 2023 Australian Bureau of Statistics - and yet 92% of women don't report their most recent sexual assault. A new report is calling for legal literacy among victim-survivors, frontline services and legal professionals, to help victims navigate a complex criminal justice system and address high attrition rates in sexual assault cases.

items.title: Pauline Hanson suspended from the Senate for seven days | Evening News Bulletin 25 November 2025
items.summary: Pauline Hanson suspended from the Senate for seven days, Afghanistan's Taliban says Pakistan's strikes kill at least ten, Nick Kyrgios to play at Kooyong Classic as he steps up bid for Australian Open wildcard.

items.title: US judge dismisses Comey and James cases, rules Halligan appointment unlawful
items.summary: A judge in the United States has dismissed two high-profile criminal charges brought by the Trump administration against the president's perceived enemies. The judge says the administration violated the Constitution in its appointment of Lindsay Halligan to prosecute the pair, rendering the charges she brought unlawful.

items.title: 'Immediate pause' urged on 'secret' Nauru deal, after speech sparks safety concerns

items.summary: The war in Sudan, which broke out in April 2023, has killed tens of thousands of civilians.

items.title: 'Adult’ pressures hit hard as UNICEF warns teens are losing hope
items.summary: A new report from UNICEF Australia has found less than a third of Australian teens are feeling excited or hopeful about their futures. Mental health issues and anxiety around 'adult' challenges like housing and money are key drivers of declining wellbeing. For marginalised children and teens, these kind of pressures are felt even more acutely.

items.title: Government injects $41.8 million into domestic violence helpline
items.summary: Social Services Minister Tanya Plibersek has said the funding will ensure the helpline can continue to meet growing demand without delay.

items.summary: James Comey was charged in September with making false statements to Congress.

items.title: Not just a 'women's issue': New fertility guidelines bring men into focus
items.summary: Australian researchers have unveiled the first male infertility guidelines, standardising care and recognising men's significant role in fertility challenges.

items.title: Victoria Police banned racial profiling a decade ago. Has it made a difference?
items.summary: Researchers said that in 2024, Aboriginal people were 15 times more likely to be searched by Victoria Police than white people.

items.title: ASX bounces back as BHP walks away from AA
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans Financial Limited about the day's sharemarket action including a recovery on the ASX as the chance of a US rate cut in December swings back up and why BHP walked away from a second crack at Anglo American.

items.title: Bureau of Meteorology weathers website storm
items.summary: The Bureau of Meteorology's controversial website redesign carries a staggering 96 million dollar price tag. The cost blowout has drawn sharp criticism from both government ministers and the opposition. Federal Environment Minister Murray Watt has expressed deep concern over the massive expenditure, while Nationals Leader David Littleproud warns the public that the exorbitant cost will further erode trust in the agency.

items.title: COP30 deal keeps humanity 'in the fight for a liveable planet': UN chief
items.summary: Delegates to the COP30 summit in Brazil have reached an agreement to address still rising global emissions. The deal increases money to countries hit by climate change, but contains no explicit fossil fuel plan. The agreement has mollified some - and horrified others.

items.title: What Black Friday sales shopping does to your brain, and how to stay in control
items.summary: Black Friday feels like a celebration of savings, but it is also a masterclass in behavioural and brain science.

items.title: The human cost of renewables: Why Australia should build solar here
items.summary: With the renewable energy transition underway in Australia, the higher than expected uptake of solar panels has human rights groups concerned about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain. As Australia looks into developing its own solar panel industry, rights groups say government and industry should work to ensure the clean energy transition isn't at the cost of freedom.

items.title: 'A $96 million fiasco': BoM under pressure over website redesign cost blowout
items.summary: The BoM website is one of the most popular in Australia, with millions visiting each day for their weather forecasts.

items.title: Fifty schoolchildren escape mass kidnapping in Nigeria, but hundreds still missing
items.summary: If confirmed, Friday's attack on St Mary's School would be Nigeria's worst school abduction since the kidnapping of 276 girls by Boko Haram in 2014.

items.summary: The strike came a week before Pope Leo was set to land in Lebanon on his first foreign trip.

items.summary: Donald Trump has given Ukraine until Thursday to accept the US proposal to end Russia's war. But European leaders have now stepped in with different plans — more palatable for Ukraine.

items.summary: Relentless rain has lashed south-central Vietnam since late October and popular holiday destinations have been hit by several rounds of flooding.

items.title: A 'massive' number of wildlife die on our roads. Experts say protections are falling far short
items.summary: Wildlife-safe road features remain largely optional, a “nice-to-have, not need-to-have”, the author of new research warns.

items.title: How a major MAGA figure went from Trump devotee to calling quits on Congress

items.title: New names added to migration Welcome Wall at National Maritime Museum
items.summary: Two panels have been unveiled at Australia's National Maritime Museum to honour a new group of migrant families. Museum Director and CEO Ms Daryl Karp and Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke say the Monument is a celebration of the long history of migrants who have shaped modern Australia.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum
items.summary: As thousands of international students prepare to take summer holiday jobs, Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum, an expert on migrants' rights from the University of New South Wales, warns that more is needed to protect students from wage theft and abuse. She says Australia has a ‘pervasive problem’ with workplace exploitation of international students and those on temporary visas. Dr Farbenblum is speaking to SBS’s Sandra Fulloon.

items.title: Underground struggles: Illegal miners risk death in Morocco's forgotten coal town
items.summary: In one of Morocco's impoverished coal towns, illegal miners continue to risk their lives to make ends meet. In an exclusive sit-down interview with SBS News, a photojournalist has shared the harsh realities he witnessed of the miners in Jerada. Ahead of the International Mining Congress in Morocco, experts are calling for better health and safety regulations to be implemented in the country.

items.title: 'Isolation and shame': Australians are avoiding perinatal mental health support, new research reveals
items.summary: Around one in four Australians are failing to seek support when experiencing perinatal mental health issues. Experts say the data released by the Gidget Foundation highlights a lack of awareness around signs and symptoms, and ongoing stigma around the issue.

items.title: 'You don't have the freedom to leave': The human cost of Australia's solar boom
items.summary: As Australia's uptake of solar panels booms, human rights groups have raised alarm about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain.

items.title: Some world leaders make decisions while chronically sleep-deprived. Should they?
items.summary: Sleep deprivation undermines our ability to think clearly. So what should we make of leaders who say they run on just a few hours?

items.title: Owed $10,000, Khoa was left stranded on a farm with no food or funds. He's not alone

items.summary: The storm was the strongest cyclone to approach Darwin since Tracy in 1974, but there were no reports of serious injuries or damage.

items.title: Ukraine faces 'difficult choice' on US plan to end Russia's war, Zelenskyy says
items.summary: Donald Trump has given Ukraine a week to accept the proposal, which would see it cede territory, among other concessions.

items.title: Leadership spills and policy reversals: How healthy is our democracy?
items.summary: With the abandonment of its net-zero policies, and leadership spills in two of Australia's largest states, the Coalition is undergoing a period of major upheaval. So what does that mean for a Westminster democracy which analysts say depends on two different political positions to succeed.

items.summary: As the academic year ends, thousands of international students are signing on for holiday work. But if things go wrong, experts warn that few understand their legal entitlements or how to recover unpaid wages.

items.title: Why government debt matters: spoiler, it’s not just Monopoly money
items.summary: We know government debt is around $1 trillion, we've heard it's bad for younger generations -- but we don't really know what any of it means. This week, Elfy and Rania chat with Professor Richard Holden from the University of New South Wales about government debt and why it matters.

items.title: PNG questions 'what planet' the Opposition is on, after it ditches net zero support

items.title: 'Can't have it all': Australia abandons bid for COP31 climate summit
items.summary: The federal government has abruptly abandoned its bid to host the United Nations climate conference next year, conceding Turkiye will oversee the COP31. The Pacific countries and environmental activists have criticised the federal government's failure to bring the event to Adelaide.

items.title: Indonesia’s drowning island takes historic climate case to court
items.summary: Indonesia is home to more than 17,000 islands, but its smallest are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The tiny community of Pari Island is facing multiple climate-induced threats, including to its entire existence.Four people on the island are now trying to launch a landmark legal case against a European cement giant over its historic carbon emissions.

items.title: Bangladesh's former Prime Minister is sentenced to death
items.summary: Bangladesh has entered one of its most volatile political periods in decades after former prime minister Sheikh Hasina was sentenced to death after being convicted over last year’s student-led uprising. She strongly rejects the ruling as illegitimate and politically motivated, insisting she was denied a fair trial. The verdict has heightened fears of renewed unrest, deepening political polarisation, and uncertainty over who will lead the Awami League into future elections.

But it's gone much further, with the Liberals and Nationals unveiling a plan to strip climate change from the national energy regulator's list of objectives, while vowing to continue to reduce emissions by monitoring the progress of other countries.

items.title: INTERVIEW: NITV Radio talks to Dr Harry Hobbs on Victoria's treaty becoming law
items.summary: This week a treaty between Victoria and the state's First Nations people became law. Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan, First Peoples' Assembly of Victoria co-chairs Ngarra Murray and Rueben Berg signed the treaty at a formal ceremony at Government House on Thursday morning. Kerri-Lee Barry from SBS' NITV Radio has spoken with UNSW Law & Justice Associate Professor, Dr Harry Hobbs, about the historic agreement.
